ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill
Troy Hill

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I marked that the pace of this course was too fast because too many topics were cramped into the semester. I think that it would have been better to reduce the number of topics and to encourage a discussion that went in depth. It seemed like most everything that was discussed was discussed on a superficial level. For the few times that the discussion was going really in depth, it then seemed like no one was prepared for it. I definitely think the course would have been better if there were less topics covered, in other words only one topic per class rather than the two so that we could really take in the readings for one topic and carry on a discussion in depth.
We had Mark Bradford as a guest speaker twice - he's very knowledgable but sometimes hard to follow because discussions were too technical. I suggest bringing it down a notch
the ability to apply soil science concepts to real-world uses, such as research, restoration, forestry, or farming. Also, the opportunity to discuss problems and issues with peers was very useful.
The discussions and presentations by instructor, guest lecturers, and students
This course was very much open to critical analysis and discussions. The professor helped in facilitating discussions.
The field trips were unquestionably the best. I really enjoyed them and they were great opportunities to learn hands on. I would suggest having at least 4-5 fields trips a semester, at least.
I enjoyed the topic very much and the student-run discussions.
The range of topics included

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The field trips can be better

Discussion could use the most improvement. I don't think that it is necessary to have a lecture before discussion and that discussion should just run for the entire seminar. The format of lecture/discussion then another lecture/discussion made it difficult for the discussions to go anywhere.

I thought the discussions were the best part of the course while the lecture component seemed a bit redundant to me at times. I think that time could have been better used to do a briefer overview and then move into more discussion.
Trying to include a more in depth discussions on soils and less of a discussion on other topics (organic agricultre for example)

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor and TA were always available via email and appointments to meet and assist students
The instructor and TA were both friendly, knowledgeable and approachable.
Both the instructor and the TA were very receptive whenever I e-mailed. I really appreciated it. Both were definitely willing to help whenever needed.
Very helpful--Florencia and Troy availed themselves for any help we might have needed.
Excellent

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Knowing the type of soils, their characteristics, composition and limitations is useful for their conservation and management either in forest management, plantation development or ecological restoration projects. It is therefore very relevant for my overall program by helping me to better understand other courses in forestry.
My masters research is in soil science, and this course was perfect for my analysis of results, etc.

The course has relevance to my research projects, however, not necessarily to my coursework overall here at F&ES. I think it does provide information to really consider for understanding any environment and in conducting any research. I found the course valuable for my interests but not crucial to them.

I'm very interested in Soil Conservation, and it was a great overview of the topic. It seemed a bit heavy on the tropics, which I understand is Florencia's area of expertise and also where a lot of soil conservation is necessary, but it would be interesting to see more and read more from other geographical contexts.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This professor is great!
I realized that my knowledge of soils was deficient, so I pursued this course to fill this knowledge gap.
Because my masters research is in soil science

I wanted to learn more about soils because I think that it is important to consider for any socio-ecological systems. It can provide important information for understanding both land use and for understanding the dynamics between the different factors that shape a landscape.
To gain a deeper understanding of soil conservation and its practices.
I provided me with a much better understanding of soil ecology.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Very much so
Yes
The class was too lecture heavy and there wasn't enough depth because too many topics were covered, so it didn't quite live up to expectations.

The course was good--a great seminar and some very interesting discussions. I thought sometimes discussion lagged a bit and some people participated more than others, but I suppose that is how it always goes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, to a large extent.
Yes

Somewhat. There was too much covered to really feel like I gained a lot of information on any one topic, however, I think it did provide a good scope of information that gave a foundation for learning more (but on the side).
YEss
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I think all students interested in soils should take this course

It's a good course that goes in to depth about soil conservation and its practices--a lot of agroforestry practices are covered and it does focus a lot on the tropics, but discussions can be a way to bring in other areas and experiences as well.
